description.narrative: Implemented since 2005 by four INGOs, the exit phase of the LDG program aims at contributing to equitable, peaceful and sustainable exploitation of natural resources between communities. The program intends to consolidate the results achieved so far and to transfer tools and approaches previously developed to appropriate authorities and share good practices. This will be done through 1) Strengthening local land management arrangements as well as citizens' control of natural resources management, 2) Improving the performance of local government authorities in natural resources management and 3) Improving inclusive management of natural resources by local stakeholders. The desired changes are threefold: 1) pacific access to natural resources and ensuring citizens' control over the management of natural resources, capacity of local government authorities and socio-professional organizations respectively in the management of natural resources and in the delegated management of natural resources strengthened and local stakeholders (local government authorities, socio-professional organizations, small-scale farms) are equipped with tools and approaches for sustainable management of natural resources (provision of family-farm advisory tools.

Programmet för lokal demokratisk styrning (LDG) är ett program som hanteras av ett konsortium av fyra internationella enskilda organisationer (INGOs) som arbetar tillsammans sedan 2005. I detta konsortium ingår Norwegian Church Aid( NCA), Helvetas Swiss Intercooperation (från Schweiz) , SNV Netherlands Development Organisation (SNV) (från Nederländerna) och Diakonia (från Sverige). Programmet leds av Diakonia som kommer att vara ansvarig i relation till Sida genom avtal för programmets resultat, risker och finansiella förvaltning.
Denna nu aktuella insatsen har godkänts efter flera samråd med parterna om programmets syfte, dess koppling till den svenska strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Mali 2016-2020 och dess operationalisering samt insatsens varaktighet och uthållighet efter sammanlagt tolv års stöd från Sida. Parterna har enats om ansvarsfull avveckling under denna sista fjärde fasen av programmet. Detta kommer att ske genom upprättandet av ett treårigt program för perioden 2018-2020 som kommer att möjliggöra att konsolidera och utnyttja resultat, kunskaper och erfarenheter som uppnåtts under tidigare faser av programmet från 2005 till 2017.
Insatsen är utformad för att ta itu med frågor om styrning av mark och naturresurser. Detta kommer att ske genom 1) Förstärkning av lokala markförvaltningsarrangemang samt medborgerlig kontroll av naturresursförvaltningen, 2) Förbättrad kapacitet för lokala myndigheter inom naturresursförvaltningen och 3) Förbättrad inkluderande förvaltning av naturresurser av lokala intressenter och målgrupper. För att ta itu med dessa utmaningar kommer landkommissioner och andra lokala organ hantera delaktighet och konflikter i samband frågor kring naturresurser. Insatsen kommer att kontinuerligt förse det permanenta sekretariatet för jordbrukslagstiftning med stödverktyg för inrättande och operationalisering av lagstiftning kring mark och det civila samhället kommer att engagera sig i olika nivåer av nationell- och lokal politik på området. Dessutom kommer kommunerna att delegera förvaltningen av kollektiva infrastrukturer som tidigare genomförts av programmet till socio-professionella organisationer och lokala aktörer.
Budgeten är 35 MSEK för perioden 2018-2020. Av denna summa förbehåller sig Sida 1 MSEK för att utföra en extern utvärdering. Budgeten utgörs i sin helhet av medel från Sida.

The Local Democratic Governance (LDG) program is a program manged by a consortium of four International Non-Governmental Organizations (INGOs) working together since 2005. This consortium includes NCA (Norwegian Church Aid-from Norway), Helvetas Swiss Intercooperation (from Switzerland), SNV (from Netherlands) and Diakonia (from Sweden). The program is led by Diakonia who will be accountable to the Embassy for program’s performance, risk and financial management.
This phase has been accepted after several consultations regarding the aim of the program, its link with the 2016-2020 Swedish cooperation strategy with Mali and its operationalization as well as the duration of the Sida support to the Programme for twelve years. The two parties concluded to move towards a responsible phasing out during a final fourth phase of the program. This will be done through the set-up of a three-year program from 2018-2020. This last phase will enable to consolidate and capitalize on results, knowledge and experience acquired during previous phases of the program from 2005 to 2017.
The intervention is designed to tackle issues on land and natural resources governance. This will be done by 1) Strengthening local land management arrangements as well as citizen control of natural resources management; 2) Improving performance of local government authorities in natural resources management and 3) Improving inclusive management of natural resources by local stakeholders. For tackling these issues, land commissions and other local arrangements will manage inclusively conflict related to natural resources, the intervention will feed the permanent secretariat of agricultural orientation law with support tools for setting-up and opertionalization of land commissions and CSOs will engage advocacy at the level of national and local policies. In addition, the municipalities will delegate the management of collective infrastructures previously realized by the program to socio-professional organizations and local actors.
The total budget is 35 MSEK and ist is totally funded by Sida. Out of this budget, 1 MSEK will be borne by Sida for the purpose of external final evaluation

description.narrative: The reduction in the number of conflicts between actors mentioned previously as a major result of the program has been confirmed this year. Through information and awareness sessions, the population became aware of the need to prevent and manage land conflicts and others related to the exploitation of natural resources. 95% of the conflicts observed are managed at the local level by land commissions. This later is considered as a major change actor. Local legitimate powers have played a central role in informing and sensitizing communities about land commissions. The diagnosis of the capacity building needs of land commissions was carried out in several municipalities and a strengthening plan was developed and available. Inter-land commissions meetings rendered possible differrent actors including decentralized technical services, judicial authorities, local elected authorities and communities to bring together to discuss the difficulties encountered in carrying out their activities. At the end of the discussions, it was agreed to develop a community awareness strategy for the ownership of land commissions considered an an endogenous resource mobilization mechanisms. However, the issue of financing the land commissions and other watch bodies created by the program has been discussed in relation to their sustainability. Reflections in different intervention areas of the program have resulted in more or less viable solutions. For example, in Douekire (Goundam), the mayor made a personal commitment that a municipal budget line be allocated for the functionality of the watch body (CVC-Comité de Veille Citoyenne). Collaboration frameworks with local radio stations have been initiated. This has resulted in the production and brodcasting programs on instruments governing agricultural land. The program also supported the municipalities in training activities and the establishment of collective work management committees, related to, among others, procurement procedures and the monitoring of collective works (management and maintenance of investments). In the communes of Douékiré and Tonka for example, the training brought together 20 people (including 10 women). As for the setting up of management committees for collective works, this concerned, for example, the pastoral well. One of the achievements in gender mainstreaming was the awareness of populations on the COVID-19 disease. Women participated also in various capacity building activities. The participation rate of women in different activities varies between 25 and 30%. Other activities such as advocacy for the choice of women and young people during training and other capacity building have made significant achievement. In the HELVETAS intervention areas, out of ten, 3 partner municipalities have more than 3 women in the land commissions and out of 10 citizen's watch committees 2 are chaired by women. In Madina Sacko (circle of Banamba), a process of revitalization made it possible to entrust a woman with the presidency of the citizen's watch committee (CVC) on the management of natural resources. Freedom of speech, taking initiatives for more accountability, involvement in the management of collective works are other achievements of the program with regard to women. The program has certainly contributed to changing the behavior of users of natural resources and the framework for collaboration between various relevant actors involved in the management of natural resources and agricultural land.However, some important challenges remain to be overcome. The following constitutes among others some of these challenges:- Ensure the sustainability of land commissions as well as Watch comittees after the end of the program- Strengthen networking and intercommunalities within the framework of Natural Resources Management;- Transfer the work tools of the land commissions and Watch Committees to local authorities for the pursuit of actions after the end of the program;- Support land commissions in the approval process of reconciliation reports relating to conflicts related to the exploitation of natural resources by the competent courts
